abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is adjudged
            satisfactory overall, and project sustainability is likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were found to be
            satisfactory. Key lessons learned include the following: The
            project demonstrates the synergy betwee macroeconomic
            stabilization and structural reforms: reaping the full
            benefits of structural reform depends heavily on fiscal
            discipline and avoidance of inflationary pressures. Careful
            and extensive preparation, including a dtrong background of
            economic and sector work, extensive collaboration with
            government, consultation with stakeholders and coordination
            with other suppliers of external assistance, and is a
            necessary but not sufficient condition for execution of
            complex adjustment. Restructuring of the government, the
            civil service and the budget must have political leadership
            and be based on decisions about the future role of the
            public sector. Attempting to introduce a new system of
            expenditure prioritization and budget allocation by
            superimposing it on an existing, inadequate budgeting system
            is not likely to be successful. Including technical
            assistance components in adjustment operations invariably
            results in closing well after disbursement of
            performancerelated tranches, and delays ICR preparation,
            thus reducing the ICR's influence on shaping future
            operations. This can be remedied by making the technical
            assistance a separate credit.
